Table 5 Entry Catalyst MEA conversion (%) EI selectivity (%) Refs. 1 P19-Cs1.8-Ba3.3-Si88 60.8 82.7 our work 2 Acid-Mt-24-1050 61.9 38.8 [2] 3 ZnO-ZSM-5 97.1 10.7 [3] 4 Cs2O-P2O5/H-ZSM-5 100 7.1 [4] 5 Si1Na0.1P0.03 21.4 67.8 [6] 6 Si50Cs1.2Fe1.0 76.7 37.5 [9] 7 WO3-SiO2 45.0 66.0 [9] The synergistic effect of acidity/alkalinity of the P-Cs-Ba-Si catalyst on dehydration of monoethanolamine to ethyleneimine Anxin Peng Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis a 1 Xinzhou Pan Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation a 1 Cuina Peng Supervision Software Project administration a Yizhong Lu Validation Supervision b Cheng Yang Supervision Resources Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering University of Jinan Jinan 250022 China aSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, China b School of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, China School of Materials Science and Engineering University of Jinan Jinan 250022 China bSchool of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. The dehydration of monoethanolamine (MEA) is an important chemical reaction for the synthesis of nitrogen-containing fine chemicals, but the reactive hydroxyl and amine functional groups of the MEA molecule make it difficult to selectively obtain the specified products. In this study, the basic metal barium and cesium were introduced on the SiO2 support by sequential impregnation method, and the support and catalyst were modified by phosphoric acid (phosphate) to form CsPO3, Cs4Ba(PO3)6 and other compounds to prepare P-Cs-Ba-Si composite oxide solid base catalyst. Varying the loading of cesium showed that the highly dispersed CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 produced stable acid and alkali active centers on the catalyst surface, thus achieving effective regulation of the dehydration reaction path of MEA. The acidic sites of the catalysts improved the intermolecular dehydration of MEA, while the basic sites improved the intramolecular dehydration of MEA. The high selectivity of ethyleneimine (EI) depended on the synergistic effect of the weakly acidic/weakly basic sites of the catalysts. In the fixed bed continuous reaction system, the conversion of MEA reached 60.8 % with the EI selectivity of 82.7 %, and 240 h of continuous operation showed good stability. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Monoethanolamine Ethyleneimine P-doped SiO2 Composite oxide Acid and alkali centers Abbreviations MEA monoethanolamine EI ethyleneimine AE 1-aziridineethanol PIP piperazine TEDA triethylenediamine PY pyrazine XRD X-ray diffraction FESEM field emission scanning electron microscopy EDS energy dispersive spectrometer BET Brunauer-Emmett-Teller TPD temperature programmed desorption DRIFTS diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy IUPAC International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Monoethanolamine (MEA) dehydration is an important chemical reaction for the synthesis of valuable nitrogen-containing fine chemicals such as ethyleneimine (EI), piperazine (PIP), triethylenediamine (TEDA), ethylenediamine, pyrazine (PY) and alkylpyrazines. Liquid acid and/or bases were initially used as catalysts in the homogeneous processes [1], but the process not only requires high equipment, but also has serious environmental pollution problems. Compared with the homogeneous process, the gas-phase catalytic dehydration of MEA over solid catalysts [2] is highly efficient and environmentally friendly. The application prospect is much broader and has attracted extensive attention from both academia and industry. However, the reaction of MEA over solid acid/base catalysts is very complex due to the presence of the highly active hydroxyl and amine groups in the MEA molecule. They are polar substituents that have a polarising effect on the carbon atoms to which they are bonded and are highly reactive over the catalyst. According to the literature [2], the main reactions of MEA conversion on solid acid/base catalysts include 1,2-elimination reaction (1,2-EM), deamination reaction (DEA), intramolecular dehydration (Intra) and intermolecular dehydration (Inter), and the reaction network is shown in Scheme 1 . During the dehydration of MEA, in addition to the primary reaction, the secondary reaction of the primary product may produce other by-products such as 1-aziridineethanol (AE), PIP and TEDA, etc. Both the catalyst and the reaction conditions affect the extent of the MEA reaction. Therefore, there are always many products in the gas phase dehydration reaction of MEA, and it is still difficult to synthesize specific products such as EI and AE. According to the literature [3,4], the most studied MEA gas phase dehydration catalysts were oxides and mixed oxides such as alumina, silica, zeolite and molecular sieve. Anand et al. [3] pointed out that when zeolite or molecular sieve was used as catalyst, the dehydration products of MEA were mainly intermolecular dehydration condensation products (PIP and its derivatives, TEDA and PY and its derivatives). Shimasaki et al. [5,6] pointed out that in phosphorus-containing catalysts, phosphorus produced acidic strength to control the acidity of the catalyst, but also produced basicity, which created a good catalytic environment for catalytic reactions. Alkaline earth metals and alkaline earth metal oxides were alkaline due to the presence of bridged oxygen atoms or surface hydroxides, which can play a subtle role in regulating the acid and alkali sites on the catalyst surface. Kong et al. [7,8] loaded both Cs2O and P2O5 on silica by impregnation and found that the Cs2O-P2O5/SiO2 catalysts would selectively produce EI by MEA dehydration, when the active site of the loaded cesium phosphate catalysts was the Cs4P2O7 phase, and the less acidic silica was able to inhibit intermolecular condensation. Sun [9] pointed out that if the cocatalyst component was introduced into the Si-Cs-P composite oxide catalyst, the oxide of barium was the most suitable. An appropriate amount of barium oxide can make the catalyst produce a proper acidity, which was suitable for the intramolecular dehydration reaction of MEA. The presence of an excessive amount of barium oxide will increase the basicity of the catalyst and promote the deamination of MEA to produce acetaldehyde and ultimately AE. However, the catalytic role of the co-catalyst has not been studied in depth. In addition, Huang et al. [2] first investigated the effect of acid activated montmorillonite (Acid-Mt) on the dehydration performance of MEA. It was found that although the catalytic activity of Acid-Mt catalysts was low, they might be catalysts or effective carriers for acid-base synergistic catalysis. On the basis of Huang 's research, Yang et al. [1] introduced Cs2O and P2O5 to prepare the Cs2O-P2O5/Acid-MMT catalyst, and found that EI could be selectively synthesized by modified catalysts by basic Cs2O and acidic P2O5 [10], but the stability of this catalyst remains to be studied. Among the many products of MEA dehydration, the product distribution requires the synergistic effect of the acidic or basic sites of catalysts. Wang et al. [11] introduced phosphorus and cesium on γ-Al2O3 to obtain acid-base bifunctional Cs-P/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. It was found that the content of phosphorus and cesium can affect the strength of acidic/basic sites on the catalyst. Li et al. [12] found that the loading of cesium on the Ba2P2O7 could adjust the acidity and alkalinity. In addition, due to the acidic properties of SiO2, its alkalinity can be adjusted and thus improve its acidity after the introduction of alkaline components [13]. Moreover, it has a weak carbon deposition ability [14], which can prolong the service life of the catalyst. Therefore, silica is considered to be a good support for acid-base bifunctional catalysts [15]. In this study, silica was selected as the carrier due to its high stability, large specific surface area and enhanced dispersion of the active phase. Barium and cesium with alkaline were then introduced on the SiO2 carrier by sequential impregnation method. In addition, phosphoric acid (phosphate) was used to adjust the acidic sites of the catalysts. A series of catalysts with different loadings of cesium (P-Cs-Ba-Si) were prepared and were systematically characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), nitrogen adsorption, Raman spectroscopy, temperature programmed desorption of NH3 or CO2 (NH3-TPD or CO2-TPD), pyridine-adsorbed in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) and Hammett indicator method. The catalytic performances of the P-Cs-Ba-Si catalyst was evaluated by the MEA dehydration experiments. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents Monoethanolamine (C2H7NO), BaHPO4 (98 %) and (NH4)3PO4∙3H2O (98 %) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd., H3PO4 (85 %) was purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd., and CsNO3 was purchased from Shanghai Aladin Biochemical Co., Ltd. The reagents were used as received without extra treatment. All the reagents used in this study were analytical reagents (AR). Deionized water was used in all experiment process. 2.2 Preparation of the P-Cs-Ba-Si catalysts P-Cs-Ba-Si composite oxide catalysts were prepared by sequential equal volume impregnation method, denoted as P19-Csx-Ba3.3-Si88, where the subscript is the theoretical atomic ratio of the corresponding element in the catalyst. Taking P19-Cs1.8-Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst as an example, the specific preparation process is as follows: 3.6 g of CsNO3 and 1.3 g of (NH4)3PO4∙3H2O were added to deionized water. The mixture was stirred to form a uniform solution. After that, 7 g Ba3.3-Si88 was immersed in the above solution for 12 h to adsorb all the solution and then was dried at 80 °C for 12 h. The dried solid was grounded and placed in a furnace for calcination at 600 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 1.7 °C/min. Finally, a white powder was obtained, which was named as the P19-Cs1.8-Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst. Preparation of Ba3.3-Si88: 14.4 g of H3PO4, 290 g of deionized water and 7.2 g of BaHPO4 were mixed evenly to form a transparent solution. 50 g of SiO2 was impregnated in the above solution and was left for 5 h to fully adsorb the solution, and then was dried at 100 °C for 12 h. After that the dried SiO2 loaded with phosphate species was calcined at 800 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. The obtained solid was named as Ba3.3-Si88. 2.3 Catalysts characterization XRD patterns were obtained by an X-ray spectrometer (SmartLab SE, Rigaku, Japan) equipped with a monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 30 mA). The samples were scanned from 10 to 80° at a step size of 0.02°. The morphology of the catalyst was characterized by FESEM (ZEISS Gemini 300, Germany) with an accelerating voltage of 2 kV. In addition, the energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) was used to test the element content of the catalysts. The specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of the catalysts were obtained from nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at -196 °C on a KoBu-X1000 (Builder, China). Raman spectra of catalysts were characterized by a Raman spectrometer (inVia Plus, Renishaw). The excitation wavelength was 532 nm. CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD were conducted to characterized the acidity/basicity of the catalyst by a chemisorption instrument (PCA-1200, China). The alkali strength of the catalysts was determined with Hammett indicator method. The 0.1 g uniform powder catalyst sample was weighed in a conical flask, 5 ml anhydrous cyclohexane was added, and then 2 drops of Hammett indicator solution were added to observe the color change of the indicator. If the Hammett indicator was alkaline, the alkali strength of the sample was greater than that of the indicator, otherwise, the alkali strength of the sample was less than that of the indicator. The alkali strength of the indicator was divided by the dissociation constant pKBH. The distribution of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on the catalysts was conducted by the pyridine-adsorbed in situ DRIFTS (Nicolet 6700, Thermo Fisher Scientific). Before measurement, the samples were made into self-supporting thin slices. The samples were evacuated in the analysis cell at 400 °C for 2 h to remove water and impurities, and then cooled down to the pick-up point temperature to collect the infrared spectrum as the background reference. Then, pyridine was introduced into the analysis cell and equilibrated for 30 min. After the catalysts were saturated by pyridine, the spectra were collected after vacuum desorption at the point temperature for 30 min. The test point was 150 °C. 2.4 Catalytic test The dehydration of MEA was carried out in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor (inner diameter 9 mm), which was filled with 3 mL of 20–40 mesh catalyst. The reaction conditions were set at 420 °C and atmospheric pressure. The liquid flow rate was controlled by a heating type advection pump (2PB-2010-JR) within 0.03 mL/min, and nitrogen as the carrier gas with a flow rate of 70 mL/min. Before the reaction, the catalyst bed was pre-flowed with nitrogen at 70 mL/min at 420 °C to remove the oxygen and water adsorbed on the surface of the catalysts. The products were collected with a condensing unit (Fig. 1 ) and then were analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Fuli GC7890 II) equipped with a PEG2W column (length: 30 m, internal diameter: 0.53 mm, film thickness: 1 um) and hydrogen flame ion detector (FID). To note, the products were labelled as other products (Others) except for representative substances such as EI, AE, PIP, TEDA, etc. where EI stands for MEA intramolecular dehydration, AE is representative of MEA deamination products, and PIP and TEDA represent MEA intermolecular dehydration products. The conversion of MEA was calculated using Eq. (1). The molar selectivity of other specific products was calculated with Eq. (2). (1) Conversion of MEA ( % ) = Initial moles of MEA − remaining moles of MEA Initial moles of MEA × 100 % (2) Selectivity of product A ( % ) = Moles of product A Consumed moles of MEA × 100 % A represented the target product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD analysis Fig. 2 was the XRD patterns of P-Cs-Ba-Si catalysts with different cesium contents. As shown in Fig. 2, all samples showed the (004) crystal plane of SiO2 at 21.76°. There were no other peaks detected in the sample of Ba3.3-Si88, which indicated that the barium was well dispersed on the surface of the catalysts. For the series of catalysts of P-Cs-Ba-Si with different cesium content, there were (301) at 23.61°, (111) at 24.90°, (211) at 27.50° and (212) at 36.15° representing monoclinic CsPO3. Trigonal Cs4Ba(PO3)6 were also observed in all the samples, which included (210) at 23.51°, (112) at 24.92°, (300) at 26.75°, (103) at 30.70° and (410) at 41.36°. With the increase of cesium loading, the intensity of diffraction peak at 21.76°decreased gradually. It was attributed to the decreasing of SiO2 content in the catalysts. When the loading of cesium was increased so that the atomic ratio of cesium was increased from 1.4 to 1.8, the intensity of the diffraction peaks at 23.5° and 26.75° gradually increased, indicating that the number of (301) crystal plane of CsPO3 crystal and (210) and (300) crystal planes of Cs4Ba(PO3)6 in the catalysts increased, and the diffraction peaks became relatively sharp, meaning that the crystallinity of CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 crystals was becoming more and more crystalline. Most of the diffraction peaks in the P19-Cs1.8-Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst disappeared, showing that excessive cesium loading caused serious agglomeration of CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 and destroyed the crystal structure. From the above results, the addition of cesium affected the crystal phase composition of the catalysts. The effects of adding cesium species on the micromorphology of the P-Cs-Ba-Si catalysts will be further investigated. 3.2 FESEM characterizations Fig. 3 was the FESEM images of the P-Cs-Ba-Si catalysts with different cesium contents. The microstructure of Ba3.3-Si88, P19-Cs1.4-Ba3.3-Si88, P19-Cs1.6-Ba3.3-Si88 and P19-Cs2.0-Ba3.3-Si88 behaved the coral shape with different branch size (Fig. 3a–d). The branch size of coral for Ba3.3-Si88 catalysts was the smallest, which was ca. 66–133 nm. With modified phosphorus and cesium species, the branch size had increased to some extent, which probably was due to the formation of recombination of barium species through reacting with phosphoric acid and cesium nitrate to form new species. The XRD results verified the formation of Cs4Ba(PO3)6 (Fig. 2). P19-Cs2.0-Ba3.3-Si88 had the extremely different micromorphology, which were large blocks with relatively smooth edges and corners, but without branches. It was possibly attributed to the formation of CsPO3, considering the results of XRD (Fig. 2). Fig. 4 was the EDS results of the P19-Cs1.8-Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst. The species of phosphorus, cesium and barium were uniformly dispersed onto the SiO2 support, which indicated the modification of cesium, barium and phosphorus species did not affect the dispersion of active sits on the support. However, the different cesium loadings had the various effects on the microstructure of the catalysts, which might also affect the pore distributions. The specific surface area, pore volume and radium of the catalysts will be further investigated. 3.3 The characterization of physical adsorption Fig. 5 and Table 1 showed the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and texture properties of P-Cs-Ba-Si catalysts with different cesium contents. From Table 1, it can be seen that the specific surface area of Ba3.3-Si88 carrier was 10.99 m2/g with an average pore size of 8.37 nm, which was a substantial decrease in both specific surface area and pore size relative to SiO2 (specific surface area of 274.47 m2/g with a pore size of 13.1 nm). This was because barium and phosphorus oxides were highly dispersed on SiO2 during equal volume impregnation, and the oxide after calcination entered the silica pore channels, which made the catalyst specific surface area decrease, pore channels become narrower and effective pore size become smaller while modulating the acidity and alkalinity of silica surface. According to the classification of the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), the N2-isothermal adsorption-desorption curve of SiO2 in Fig. 5 belonged to type IV [16,17], with the presence of hysteresis loop at P/P0>0.8, and the presence of inflection point but no adsorption saturated platform, which can be regarded as the presence of mesoporous structure in the carrier, but the pore structure was not very regular. On the other hand, the adsorption-desorption isothermal curve of Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst belonged to type II, which indicated that the catalyst was a nonporous carrier, and this change in pore structure confirmed the deposition of barium and phosphorus oxides into the pores. After the introduction of alkali metal cesium, the adsorption-desorption isotherm curves of P-Cs-Ba-Si catalyst were the combination of type II and type III, meaning that the adsorption of the catalysts was weakened, and an increase in adsorption was observed at relative pressures of 0.95–0.99 with a hysteresis loop. In conjunction with Table 1, this was due to the formation of cavities by the generation of CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 grains, so that the interactions between the cesium, barium and with the carrier as well as the deposition of the active components in the pores led to a gradual decrease in the specific surface area and pore volume of the catalysts. 3.4 Raman analysis Fig. 6 was the Raman spectra of P-Cs-Ba-Si catalysts with different cesium contents. There was no significant difference in the Raman spectra of the catalysts obtained by the two Raman tests, indicating that the P-Cs-Ba-Si catalyst had good uniformity. It can be seen from the Fig. 6a that the band at 460cm−1 belonged to the bending vibration of Si-O molecular bond [18,19], and the band at 988 cm−1 was attributed to the symmetrical stretching vibration of Si-O-Si molecular bond [20,21], both of which were the characteristic Raman peaks of silica. The Raman spectrum of catalyst Fig. 6b was similar to that of Fig. 6a, and the introduction of phosphorus and barium changed the bond energy of Si-O-Si, resulting in a change in the intensity of the Raman peak at 988 cm−1 [22]. In the Raman spectra of P-Cs-Ba-Si composite catalyst (Fig. 6c–e), the bands of 1020 cm−1,920 cm−1,533 cm−1 and 420 cm−1 were all part of the internal vibration of PO4 [23,24] tetrahedron in Cs4Ba(PO3)6 crystal [25], where 1020 cm−1 corresponded to ν3(A1g+Eg), 920 cm−1 was assigned to ν1(A1g), 533 cm−1 represented ν4(Eg), and 420 cm−1 denoted ν2(Eg) [26,27]. The band at 1266 cm−1 was associated with the symmetric stretching vibration of the metaphosphate unit (P-O)nb in monoclinic crystal CsPO3 [28,29]. The band at 1140 cm−1 was characteristic of Cs-O-P mixed phase, and the band at 640 cm−1 was assigned to the Cs-O-Ba mixed phase. The vibrational peaks at 265 cm−1 and 330 cm−1 were the external vibrational modes induced by the vibrations of Ba-O [30], Cs-O and PO4 tetrahedra, respectively [31,32]. The Raman peaks in catalyst (Fig. 6f) showed a substantial decrease in intensity and broadening of peak width, indicating that excessive cesium loading caused the molecular structure of CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 to be disrupted and poorly crystallised, a phenomenon that was consistent with the XRD results. Therefore, the Raman characterization further confirmed the formation of the physical phase structure of CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 in the P-Cs-Ba-Si composite oxide catalysts, and the effect of the formation of CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 on the surface acidity and alkalinity of the catalyst will be further studied. 3.5 Acidity and alkalinity Fig. 7 a showed the surface acidity strength distribution of the catalyst samples measured by NH3-TPD. In the samples, it can be seen that there were two weak peaks in the range of 120–250 °C and 250–600 °C, respectively [33]. It indicated the existence of two types of acidic sites on the surface of the samples, weak and moderately strong acids. Table 2 calculated and summarized the acid site distribution of P-Cs-Ba-Si catalyst. Combined with Fig. 7a and Table 2, it was found that with the increase of cesium content, the NH3 desorption peak temperature of the catalyst moved to the low temperature region, and the area of the NH3 desorption peak gradually decreased. This meant that acidic sites existed on the surface of the P-Cs-Ba-Si catalysts, and the addition of barium and cesium can cover the acidic sites, resulting in a decrease in the number of acidic sites and a decrease in the acid strength of the catalyst. This was also related to the high dispersion of compounds such as CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 formed by the interaction between barium, cesium and phosphorus on the catalyst. The introduction of cesium led to a change in the phase composition of the catalyst, producing compounds such as CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6. These substances were weakly acidic and at the same time covered the strongly acidic sites on the surface of the Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst. Therefore, the loading of cesium would reduce the acid strength of the catalyst. Fig. 7b showed the surface alkalinity intensity distribution of the catalyst samples measured by CO2-TPD. According to the CO2-TPD spectra, the catalysts showed desorption peaks in the ranges of 120–250 °C and 250–600 °C, respectively [34]. It indicated the presence of two types of alkaline sites on the surface of the samples, weakly alkaline and moderately strongly alkaline. Combined with Table 2, it was found that contrast to NH3-TPD, the temperature of the CO2 desorption peak of the catalyst moved towards the high temperature region with increasing cesium content, while the area of the CO2 desorption peak gradually increased. This indicated that increasing the loading of cesium, the basicity of the catalyst was enhanced, and the number of basic sites was increased. This change can be attributed to the formation and increase of CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 phases. The catalyst strengths measured by Hammett indicator method was weakly alkaline (3.9<H—<7.2), which may be related to the high dispersion of CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 on the catalyst. Combined with the results of NH3-TPD for the catalyst in Fig. 7a, the compounds such as CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 generated by the synergistic interaction of barium and cesium on the catalyst surface were the main factors affecting the acid-base properties of the catalyst surface. Changing the loading of cesium can obtain highly dispersed CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 on the surface of the catalyst. As a result, a stable surface acid and basic active centers was generated, which can achieve effective regulation of the MEA dehydration reaction path. Fig. 8 showed the pyridine-adsorbed in situ DRIFTS spectra of the P-Cs-Ba-Si catalysts. The properties of the acidic sites on the P-Cs-Ba-Si catalyst and its effect on the dehydration of MEA were investigated. The band observed near 1446 cm−1 in the figure was the characteristic peak of pyridine chemisorption on Lewis acid sites. The band near 1488 cm−1 was the result of the co-interaction of Lewis acid and Brønsted acid with pyridine. The band near 1540 cm−1 was the characteristic peak of the interaction of Brønsted acid with pyridine [35,36]. It can be seen from the Fig. 8 that after the introduction of basic metals barium and cesium into the SiO2 support under the modification of phosphoric acid (phosphate). There were Lewis acid sites, Brønsted acid sites, and coexistence of Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites on the P-Cs-Ba-Si catalyst. With the increase of cesium loading of the catalyst, the characteristic peak of the Lewis acid site moved to the low wave number. This implied that the Lewis acid strength of the catalyst was weakened [37,38], but there was no significant difference in the acid strength of the Brønsted acid of each catalyst. Combined with Table 3 , it was found that the P19-Cs1.4-Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst with the highest MEA conversion had stronger Lewis and Brønsted acid, which proved that the surface acidity of the catalyst promoted the conversion of MEA molecules. And the P19-Cs1.8-Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst with the best EI selectivity exhibited weak Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. It suggested that the weak surface acidity generated by the interaction between barium, cesium and phosphorus was beneficial to the intramolecular conversion of MEA to EI. 3.6 Catalytic performance Tables S1 and 4 showed the MEA dehydration activity and product distribution under different P-Cs-Ba-Si composite catalysts. The reaction conditions were: reaction temperature 300–420 °C, reaction time 10 h, MEA volume space velocity 0.6 h−1, and carrier gas nitrogen flow rate 70 mL/min. From Table S1, it can be found that the catalysts in Entry 1, 4, 8 and 12 had the same MEA conversion. The reaction temperature of Ba3.3-Si88,P19-Cs1.4-Ba3.3-Si88 and P19-Cs1.6-Ba3.3-Si88 catalysts to achieve about 60 % conversion was lower than that of P19-Cs1.8-Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst, but the EI selectivity was not high. This can indicate that the selectivity of the catalysts was mainly determined by the intrinsic properties of the catalysts. Combining Tables S1 and 4, it can be seen that that the P19-Cs1.8-Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst had the best catalytic performance at 420 °C, the conversion of MEA was 60.8 %, and the selectivity of EI was 82.7 %. As Table 4 shown, it can also be found that the Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst could convert 99.6 % of MEA. It mainly involved the intermolecular dehydration reaction, which obtained PIP, TEDA and other intermolecular dehydration products with the selectivity of 43.0 %, 26.1 % and 30.6 %, respectively. With adding the cesium species, the conversion of MEA gradually decreased, which indicated the cesium species was not conducive to the catalytic performances of the catalyst. The selectivity of EI and AE increased sharply with the increasing of cesium while PIP and TEDA decreased gradually (Entry 3–5, Table 4). As the results of NH3-TPD, the increasing of cesium enhance the basic sites while weaken the acidic sites. It indicated the basic sites improved the intramolecular dehydration of MEA while acidic sites improved intermolecular dehydration (Entry 3, 4, Table 4). The selectivity of the EI depended on the basic/acidic sites of the catalysts. In addition, the colour of the products gradually becomes lighter when the cesium content increased, which indicated the basic sites can inhibit the occurrence of polymerization reactions of intermediates. Based on these results, we proposed a reaction network for MEA dehydration on P-Cs-Ba-Si composite oxide catalysts. It mainly included intermolecular dehydration reaction (Inter), intramolecular dehydration reaction (Intra), and deamination reaction (DEA), and the reaction network was shown in Scheme 2 . 3.7 Stability of catalysts Subsequently, the stability of the catalyst was investigated under the same reaction conditions described above, and the effects of reaction time on MEA conversion and EI selectivity at different time intervals were studied (Fig. 9 ). In the fixed-bed continuous reaction system, the conversion of MEA and the selectivity of EI fluctuated slightly within 240 h, but both could be maintained at about 60.5 % and 80.0 %, respectively. This showed that the P19-Cs1.8-Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst maintained high activity and good stability for the synthesis of EI by intramolecular dehydration of MEA. To highlight the results of this study, the previous reports about the catalytic performances of MEA conversion were listed in Table 5 . As shown in Table 5, P19-Cs1.8-Ba3.3-Si88 had the higher catalytic performances and the higher selectivity of EI than the Acid-Mt-24-1050 or WO3-SiO2 [2]. Compared with other catalysts, the selectivity of EI in this study was high though the conversion of MEA was lower. On the P-Cs-Ba-Si composite oxide catalyst, the increase of cesium content led to the decrease of acid strength and the increase of alkali strength of the catalyst (Figs. 7 and 8). Combined with the activity evaluation results of P-Cs-Ba-Si series catalysts (Table 4), the MEA conversion was gradually reduced with the decrease of acidity and the increase of alkalinity of the catalyst. The catalyst with stronger acidity, namely Ba3.3-Si88, exhibited a high MEA conversion of 99.6 % close to 100 %, while the MEA conversion was only 13.0 % on the P19-Cs2.0-Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst with weaker acidity. This result is consistent with the previous research conclusions [1,2,6], which can prove that the acidic sites of the catalyst play a catalytic role in the MEA dehydration reaction. The acid-base property of the catalyst is an important factor affecting the reaction pathway of MEA dehydration. Combining Figs. 7 and 8, the acidity of the catalyst gradually decreased and the basicity gradually increased with the increase of cesium loading, but the selectivity of EI showed a tendency of first increasing and then decreasing. This indicates that the acidity and basicity of the catalyst do not show a positive correlation with the selectivity of EI, and the synthesis of EI requires a suitable range of catalyst acidity and basicity, which is jointly influenced by the acidic and basic sites. When the catalyst has weaker acidic and basic centres (3.9<H—<7.2), it is more conducive to the MEA intramolecular dehydration. Therefore, a certain intensity of acid-base active center synergy can make the intramolecular dehydration of MEA highly selective synthesis of EI. This conclusion is in line with the findings of previous literature [5] that the synthesis of EI is catalyzed by acid-base synergy. Meanwhile, as the acid strength of the catalyst gradually decreases, the selectivity of MEA intermolecular dehydration products decreases. This result can be attributed to the fact that the MEA intermolecular dehydration reaction is a bimolecular reaction, which requires two acidic sites and is more dependent on the acidity of the catalyst [9]. The strong acidity of the catalyst is more favorable for the generation of the intermolecular dehydration condensation products. In our experiment, it can be observed that when the acidity of the catalyst weakened, the selectivity of TEDA changed faster than that of PIP. This indicated that the formation step of TEDA was more sensitive to the change of catalyst acidity. When the basicity of Ba3.3-Si88, P19-Cs1.4-Ba3.3-Si88 and P19-Cs1.6-Ba3.3-Si88 catalysts was weak, there was no AE production in the dehydration of MEA. After increasing the cesium content to a certain alkali strength of the catalyst, the AE selectivity of the P19-Cs1.8-Ba3.3-Si88 catalyst broke through 0 and reached 5.6 %. The AE selectivity gradually increased by continuing to increase the cesium content. AE is obtained by the secondary reaction of MEA intramolecular dehydration product EI and MEA deamination product acetaldehyde. The basic sites of the catalyst can promote the MEA deamination reaction to form acetaldehyde [1,2], which in turn promotes the generation of AE and the increase of AE selectivity. In summary, on the P-Cs-Ba-Si composite oxide catalyst, the acidity of the catalyst weakened and the alkalinity increased with the increase of cesium content and the increase of CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 phases formed by the synergistic action of barium and cesium. The acidic site improved the intermolecular dehydration of MEA, making the selectivity of PIP, TEDA and other products high. The basic sites improved the intramolecular dehydration of MEA, which led to the increase of AE selectivity. The selectivity of EI depended on the basic/acidic sites of the catalysts, and the synergistic effect of weak acid and weak base sites can obtain high selectivity of EI. 4 Conclusions In this study, P-Cs-Ba-Si composite oxide catalysts were prepared by introducing alkali metals barium and cesium on SiO2 carriers by sequential impregnation method, respectively, while modifying the carriers and catalysts by phosphoric acid (phosphate) to form compounds such as CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6. The loadings of cesium were varied and applied to the MEA dehydration reaction at high temperature and atmospheric pressure with nitrogen as the carrier gas. It was found that the highly dispersed CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 on the catalyst could produce stable acid and alkali active centers on the surface of the catalyst, so as to realize the effective regulation of the MEA dehydration pathway. The results showed that the acidic sites of the catalysts improved the intermolecular dehydration of MEA, resulting in high selectivity for PIP, TEDA and other products. In contrast, the basic sites improved the intramolecular dehydration of MEA, resulting in high selectivity of AE. The selectivity of EI, on the other hand, depended on the basic/acidic sites of the catalysts, and the synergistic action of weak acid and weak base centers catalyzed the highly selective synthesis of EI from MEA. The catalyst shows good stability in the fixed bed reactor system for 240 h. This result is of great significance for the development of high-performance solid base catalysts for the dehydration of MEA to specified nitrogen-containing fine chemicals. coredata.dc:description: The dehydration of monoethanolamine (MEA) is an important chemical reaction for the synthesis of nitrogen-containing fine chemicals, but the reactive hydroxyl and amine functional groups of the MEA molecule make it difficult to selectively obtain the specified products. In this study, the basic metal barium and cesium were introduced on the SiO2 support by sequential impregnation method, and the support and catalyst were modified by phosphoric acid (phosphate) to form CsPO3, Cs4Ba(PO3)6 and other compounds to prepare P-Cs-Ba-Si composite oxide solid base catalyst. Varying the loading of cesium showed that the highly dispersed CsPO3 and Cs4Ba(PO3)6 produced stable acid and alkali active centers on the catalyst surface, thus achieving effective regulation of the dehydration reaction path of MEA. The acidic sites of the catalysts improved the intermolecular dehydration of MEA, while the basic sites improved the intramolecular dehydration of MEA. The high selectivity of ethyleneimine (EI) depended on the synergistic effect of the weakly acidic/weakly basic sites of the catalysts. In the fixed bed continuous reaction system, the conversion of MEA reached 60.8 % with the EI selectivity of 82.7 %, and 240 h of continuous operation showed good stability.
